comments:
Eclipse 2.1 I20030312

After upgrading Eclipse if I double click a breakpoint (Breakpoints view) on a 
class file outside my workspace I get the stack trace bellow. If the file is 
in my workspace all is fine.

I do not have binary projects. Instead, I use the Target Platform preferences 
page (under Plugin Development). Select Not in Workspace in order to select 
the plugins you would like to compile/run against.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.ui 4 995 Mar 12, 2003 14:23:59.02
!MESSAGE The classfile is not on the classpath

The debugger does not support breakpoints in external source. The question is, 
how did you create the breakpoint, and then get it associated with an external 
file?

I don't think I've done anything special. I've added the breakpoint as usual: 
double click in the beggining of the line. I don't have to do any magic to 
associate it with the external file.

I am able to reproduce this problem. Not that when I left the editor open on a 
class file that was "not in the workspace", when I upgraded to a new version of 
the SDK, I got a similar error message at startup - the editor could not be 
restored:

Normally, we automatically delete breakpoints when the classpath changes. I'm 
not sure we're receiving a delta in this case (or our plug-in was not loaded 
and thus did not receive the delta).

We add a "handle identifier" attribute of the associated java model element to 
the breakpoint marker. The handle appears to be fully qualified with the 
location of the old jar in the local file system, rather than prefixed with 
the "ECLIPSE_HOME" variable. When we try to open the breakpoint, the handle 
points to a java model element which is no longer on the classpath.

However, the underlying problem may be that we are simply missing the java 
model delta of the classpath change.

Verified that a java model delta is generated, but our plug-in is not loaded at 
the time that the delta is fired, and thus the breakpoints are not cleaned up 
properly.

NOTES:
* This problem only occurrs when a breakpoint exists in an "external" archive 
referenced by a classpath variable, and the variable (classpath) changes when 
our debug plug-in is not loaded
* This problem will not occurr frequently - it happens now because we are 
continually changing builds - but users of a stable version of eclipse will not 
be effected in day to day work
* The workaround is to delete the breakpoint and create a new one
* The error is handled - nothing bad happens (except an error dialog)
* We are unable to delete the breakpoint at startup (when it is initialized), 
as the workspace may be locked.
* We could add a more friendly verification phase when the breakpoint is double-
clicked (i.e. ensure that it is still valid)

Marking as a README for 2.1, defer enhanced verfication/cleanup for post 2.1
